subject: Re: [junit] Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: ... I disagree. Model objects representing values should be transparent, a la Naked Objects . They should let the Model objects containing business logic do
messageBody:
>So said Jason Rogers on 2003-06-13 --------------------
>On Fri, 13 Jun 2003 16:54:16 -0700, "Eric Armstrong"
><eric.armstrong@...> said:
>[snip]
>> There is no "get" in this system, but the test can still verify
>> that the internal state is as expected, using state-verification
>> methods intended for that purpose.
>
>Interesting points. My general take on the matter is that there is no
>one answer. I think the system itself will dictate the best approach.
>One thing that I do feel very strongly about is that a plethora or
>getters/setters tends to indicate that the object design is faulty.

I disagree. Model objects representing values should be transparent, a la "Naked Objects". They should let the Model objects containing business logic "do with them what they may". There is a tendency in OOP to pretend there is behavior where there is no behavior. I think that is a mistake. Some objects in the system are just bags of data. I think public fields should do nicely there. Ward Cunningham has been experimenting with ignoring the prevaling paranoia against public data. I haven't seen him write anything on it yet, but it's good to test long-standing "rules".

> I
>think that goes more for the setters than the getters. It's my
>contention, and I code this way every day of the week, that an object
>should be instantiated in a sane state. You should not need to 'new' an
>object and then turn right back around a call 1..N setter methods on it.

Indeed!

One counterexample is an object with 20 fields. Perhaps 20 set methods is clearer, at least in a language like Java with positional parameters. (In Smalltalk it's exactly the same, so it doesn't matter.) Should an object have 20 fields? Perhaps not, but some do. It is not clear that breaking that 20-field objects into four 5-field objects is any better.

<snip />
